o4Y_RP1YOV024F5xf-FM3w.text: I visited this place about 4 months ago and am just now getting to my review. I originally had a lot more to say but I have softened my tone overtime.   Service: Was great, I enjoyed speaking to the servers and I think the owner. They explained the process and options very well. They kept our drinks filled and were friendly.  Food: The food is good to a point. About 1/2 way through the meal everything just starts to taste bland and one note. The food doesn't sit in the broth's enough to add too much flavor and what little flavors is added all taste the same.   Decor: It's fine, they tried hard to make this a fresh experience but I feel like I've been in similar places many times. It reminds me of the Goth kids when I was in High School, they all hated to conform and wanted to be different but in the end they all looked the same as each other. Every "hip" restaurant these days are the same to me: Pop art, stone and concrete, and blasting some form of electronic music.   Experience: We planned on going with another couple but the cancelled at the last minute. This was a blessing because the bar seating and extremely loud music would have made it difficult to have a conversation with all four at the same time.  Go if: You've never had hot pot You really enjoy hot pot and live near Summerlin If you want to try something new and the experience is more important than flavor   Avoid if: You have a large group You're not a Hipster Foodie and care more about quality of food  than what's supposed to be cool or unique.

1GYEWB9S-qLWFHlXDOuIWA.text: I'm sure the food is good, but we had to walk out because they simply ignored us for 10mins upon walking in. cQ7Cl0nw_WrjFwKNZz8Auw.text: This place was tasty!  I have been to a shabu shabu where you cook it in water which I am not a fan of ... at Yojie, you get a few options to cook it in a tasty broth.  I tried the one with the posturized egg ... it got a little getting used to because I don't eat raw egg but after it was explained to me ... it took a little getting used to but then it was delicious!  The dessert - fruit and chocolate fondue was delicious as well.  I will be back and will bring friends/parents here too!

7aD9SNGAJld7RkPi_2GThA.text: I created a Yelp account for the sole purpose of reviewing this restaurant (and an alteration shop in the Boca Park area, see next review).   I have never had shabu shabu before, so I didn't know what to expect coming in for a late lunch during Memorial Day weekend. The restaurant was brand spankin' new and had very modern/contemporary decor.   Customer service was excellent! The staff was attentive and very helpful with the ordering process. Food was great, and fairly priced. I ordered the Geisha prime rib entree with the spicymiso broth. I also had the Japanese iced coffee, which was a bit small but 'twas delicious nonetheless. Funnyman and partner of the restaurant, Jo Koy, was there that day to support the staff. He interacted with customers and made sure that everyone had an enjoyable experience.  Overall it was a great first shabu shabu experience. I'll definitely be coming back here again.

photos.caption: Photo of Yojié Japanese Fondue - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Great dining experience! Finally met Jo Koy...he&#39;s a cool dude!

qLOteUwcJdbq8ziXafwl8Q.text: After seeing Jo Koy on the news promoting his new restaurant, I had to check it out.  And as Jo Koy stated in his interview, Yojie Japanese Fondue isn't where you dip sushi into cheese. That's what I first though when I heard the restaurant name, but behold  Japanese Fondue is another name for shabu shabu.   When I walked into the restaurant, I was surprised that there is only bar seating. That's fine if you're with one or two people, but it's harder to socialize and be seated   with larger groups.  Ordering is simple, pick your meat & size, then the dip you'd like to cook with, and depending on the dip you can also choose other sauces to dip with afterward. Each meat comes with a bowl of veggies and noodles to accompany the meats. The server mentioned their two most popular meat choices were the prime rib & Yojie's cut and the most popular dips are shabu shabu and sukiyaki. I opted for the geisha (medium sized) prime rib, shabu shabu dip with goma and ponzu sauce.   The food came out quicker than I expected. I took a lot longer figuring out the menu! The geisha size was a little smaller than I imagined. For a medium, I think I got 6 or 7 pieces of prime rib. I think with different cuts of meat you may get more slices. So next time, I'll definitely go a size up. Thankfully I had a bowl of rice and another bowl full of vegetables (cabbage, carrots, mushroom, onions), tofu, seaweed, and 2 different kinds of noodles to fill me up. Despite my poor choice in size, the meat and vegetables were all fresh and tasty even when it was dipped in the shabu shabu (which is just water). The goma and ponzu sauce were a great companion to the meat. I'll be back to try the swisher sauce!    Our server told me that they were still in their  soft opening, but have had a great turn out so far and that there will be more restaurants opening up soon! I enjoyed the ambiance and the attentive staff. Can't wait to come back and try their dessert!   Their bathroom is pretty cool too with an interesting waterfall sink!

LjMTTs5vRITDqPhcKXFA4w.text: Excellent food and excellent service.  If you're looking for a quick stop for super good food, here's your place.  We ordered the combo beef and kurabuto pork. I liked the tonkatso more, but my fiance liked the miso better.  It's also very clean and organized here. I loved that all of the waiters were very knowledgeable, helpful and quick.   I just wish they had alcohol. A cold asahi would have been perfect. We saw others with alcohol. So I'm assuming you can bring your own with a fee.  Overall, it was awesome. XGBcHn8rYo9zpN5BeQPYiA.text: OMG! You HAVE to try this Japanese fondue and Shabu Shabu spot if you're in Vegas! I know there are plenty of great places to eat who have the best this, or the best that, but seriously, Yojie's ROCKS like no other!  The food is very fresh, healthy, reasonable, DELICIOUS, and "original"! The best part about Yojie's is that the service here is absolutely top notch! The staff all love it here! Ever run into a barber or hairdresser who LOVES what they do? Well, it's the same vibe at Yojie's...  We split the Samuri sized (7 ops) Kobe Beef w/ a pot of their Spicy Miso & Tonkotsu broths, 2 sides of sauces (Goma & Ponzu), w/ brown rice. They didn't have their beer/wine license yet so we ordered their delicious Signature Green Tea... Everything was absolutely amazing!!!  We'll definitely go for it all next time and try their Japanese Wagyu Beef and get the staff to ring the gong! We ended our dinner w/ a scoop of thier Ube ice cream since we were kind of full. They offer a pretty tasty fruit & pastry chocolate fondue which we'll try and leave more space for the next time we visit!  We were fortunate to try Yojie's while JoKoy happened to be in town so that was extra special that he was there to hangout w/ his dining patrons. Both Anton & JoKoy were really hospitable and genuine guys! I guarantee if you check this place out, you will instantly be a fan of this spot! We can't wait to come back the next time!

L5FwjbfG9ObQu4UrQkQPrQ.text: I like shabu shabu and its concept. You get a plate of thinly sliced beef and "shabu shabu" the meat in hot pot (FYI Shabu shabu is onomatopoeia term, a sound that comes from stirring the meat in water or sauce). Growing up eating shabu shabu at home, I wasn't too fond of the vibe or the price here. In Japan, you can get a pack of thinly sliced beef at less than 1,000 yen ($10) so I was surprised to see them charging $15-20 a pot. Traditionally it's an affordable dish that is to be shared with a group.   I walked-in and was not greeted or seated for 15 minutes. A worker was busy on the phone which bothered me. She was friendly but not attentive. I would dock a star just for the service here.   I decided to get Yojie's cut which is angus cut and their recommended plate. They have different sizes (3oz, 5oz, 7oz, 10oz) and all plates comes with a bowl of vegetables, noodles and a choice of white or brown rice. I went with 5oz or Geisha which was $14.99 (lunch). You can also choose your dipping soup/sauce option. I went ahead with shabu shabu style and got goma and ponzu sauce.  5oz Yojie's cut came with about 10 shabu shabu meat. Shabu shabu is cooked fast, you just need to dip in water about 10 seconds and is ready to eat. Goma sauce is a sesame sauce and had rich taste to it. Ponzu was citrusy and refreshing with meat. I also got to try their swisher sauce which is my personal favorite.   5oz was not filing even after finishing their bowl of vegetables/noodle and rice. I understand they use quality meat but you are looking at about $20 with tip and tax or even more for a fairly small portion. In addition, you don't share the pot in a group. I guess Yojie has Americanized take on shabu shabu and I am not sure if I am a fan.

mBAmPVBUh2aPjb7AKt3ctA.text: "WTF is Japanese Fondue?" asks my Asian poker bud.  "No clue.  How do you know about this place?" my dumbfounded reply.  "The hot Asian dealer.  Besides fish, beef, pork, chicken; it all taste better dipped in melted cheese!" proclaims my Midwest poker bud.    Upon arriving...  "Japanese Fondue" = Shabu shabu.  No sashimi dipped in cheese for this carnivore!  This is shabu shabu for beginners.   All meals come complete with veg, rice, and noodles to finish the broth.  Ordering is simple:  1.  Choose the protein, cut, and quantity ranging from 3oz to 10oz.  Beef grades include USDA Choice, USDA Prime, Snake River Farms American Wagyu, A5 Japanese Wagyu.    2.  Choose broth.  Classic shabu shabu is a simple piece of konbu in water, spicy miso, or tonkotsu broth.  All come with appropriate dipping sauces.  A sukiyaki preparation is also offered.  Note:  every diner must order at least one set or split charges apply.  Cooking simple.  Proteins one slice at a time. Beef follows the two second rule, pork and chicken as daring as you want to be.  Dip and eat ripping hot.  Veg whenever you want.  Noodles to finish.  In the end, the A5 is outstanding.  Flash cooked.  Extremely sweet with a clean finish.  The American wagyu has good marbling and a more pronounced beef flavor.  Both showcase the best in basic shabu shabu konbu broth.  The USDA Prime rib eye is hands down the most flavorful by American standards and works in any broth.  Service is good but then again, there's nothing much required after the raw food has been delivered.    IMPORTANT:  BYOB!  Straightforward and no complaints of this small Cali chain.

yeeU_1pO58EiyD42B15qJg.text: This place was absolutely amazing , I took a group of friends here late May and the experience was superb , the service was top notch and the food was mouth wateringly amazing. If you are firmiliar with Shabu Shabu or Hot Pot type establishments you owe it to yourself to try Yojie out it is everything you love about Shabu Shabu but with its own signature flavor. They have an assortment of meats as broths you can choose from depending on your preference. The broths are made in house , the meats are high quality and the veggies are as fresh as they come this is definitely the top of my Off the Strip Vegas food spots !

yjiprbTTZbkymoMbi6mPZw.text: Yojie Japanese Fondue is one of my favorite Shabu Shabu spots in Las Vegas! I try to make a trip to Yojie whenever I'm in town! jRwsjD-N1bno0EcyuUysZg.text: I love this place!! Been here twice already, and each time still impresses me. I love the variety of options and also the variety of sauces. wz0VTNsIMO_QV82LCxrVng.text: I didn't know that Jo Koy owned this restaurant. Now that's out of the way let's take about this establishment.   It's a nice place inside but the only grumble I had was how small it was. I guess the set up is for one person per one hot plate but what if you had a big group?   On to the food..  I ordered the ribeye meat size samurai (large) with spicy miso base. I asked if they had a paste or sauce that was spicer. OMG! They warned me about it but did I listen? NOPE! The base of my hot pot was soooooo spicy. Lol! The prime rib comes out raw of course and you take a piece and dip it into the boiling broth. Give it less then 10 seconds and it's finished. Choose your sauce.. I got ponzu (soy sauce with lemon) and dipped my meat and ate my rice. I like my meat Rare so that's how I did all my meat. You're in charge of your food and you cook everything yourself. So you're the caption of your ship :-)  Will I be back again?? Probably not, unless they fix the sitting situation to handle parties of 4 or more. Also if you're short like my friend the hot pot itself it's kinda far. I don't have a problem but she did.

p3cjTfoV0bp9yZV2uRv-Eg.text: This place is pretty great. The food quality and service offered here was pretty good, they also offer a pretty large variety on protein. However, I was a little sad that they didn't offer lamb. Out of all the shabu places I been to, this is the only one where they offer the (raw) pasteurized egg as a dipping sauce. I personally didn't order the sauce but I was able to try it from my friend and it was pretty delicious. I constantly saw the waitresses checking up on customers and even helping them out in terms of cooking their food. I personally didn't get that much attention, but I'm indifferent about that because I shabu a lot and I just do my own thing. Just a minor complaint (and I'm sure it was pure accident) was that they turned off my stove before I was even done cooking/eating. Overall I really enjoyed this place and would definitely come back!

l6GD84t5uDeQvOgLAQBgqQ.text: Flavorful broths make this place much more than the shabu shabu. Very clean and friendly service!

-JlmSrtCA_GIL9y38PFFgw.text: Coming from Los Angeles, with places like little Tokyo, Koreatown and Chinatown, shabu shabu is nothing new to me.  I've tried a few of the shabu shabu places here in Las Vegas over the last few months and by far this is one of my favorites.  First off, there's plenty of parking due to the large shopping area. The Kojies lies right in the southwest corner of the lot next to a comic book store.  The decor is very plain and simple with a clean and artistic feel to the restaurant. With about 20 seats in the whole restaurant, you definitely have to make sure you come at the right time.  Your shabu shabu pot comes in 2 steps. First up being your choice of protein. They also have a salmon choice and an all vegetable choice as well. Once you pick your protein from ribeye, to pork to the Koji house special, you then move on to your choice of broth.  You have a choice of a spicy broth, a clear broth, and the tonkatsu broth.  You also get your choice of two dipping sauces. One of them being the ponzu which is my favorite.  Along with the pot and comes a vegetable medley with carrots noodles broccoli and lettuce for dipping. You also get your choice of white or brown rice and chopped green onions and garlic. If you want to kick it up a notch go ahead and ask for the house chili sauce which is made from ghost peppers.  The pot is placed on electric burner right in front of you and the fun then begins. The staff was amazingly attentive. From everything from checking to make sure our dips and broth were always full to make me sure our drinks for always refilled.    Prices were pretty decent. Around $36 for the two of us, one with the meat protein and the other one with an all vegetable and one drink.  I definitely recommend this as one of the better shabu shabu places here in Vegas.

BNoQH6cfnakJ-a9l6kJCYg.text: Wow what an experience! The food is delicious and the service is second to none. Upon entering has a cool vibe. Very clean built restaurant with art work on the right side of the walls. There's USB ports under your table to charge your phones or other devices. The menu is simple to order from. I got the kobe beef samurai size. A plate of veggies, sauce, udon, and rice come with it. The sukiyaki was the flavor of the broth I went with. Sweet and savory at the same time. For dessert I had the green tea white chocolate fondue. It's being dipped with other fruits as well. I had an amazing time. Will come again during my next visit to Vegas.  Recommendation: Sukiyaki beef and Green tea white chocolate fondue

fU1hfCkC3SPqQqnrCnwPPQ.text: Amazing food and staff!!! Everything was delicious and the customer service was excellent! Great experience and the decor is super nice and modern. I will keep coming to this place and no longer crave the hot pot places in Hawaii so much lol!

8plWQTwJ1Vj6UHg8pJ2YGw.text: We are from LA so we have gone to many good shabu shabu places in the past. This place had great reviews so we thought that we would give it a try. You get tired of eating at the hotel restaurants on the strip. The price was good for the amount of food that you get. Each set came with a bowl of veggies and noodles but we ordered an extra bowl to share. The nice part is that you don't leave smelling like food!  There is plenty of parking but we were also there around 2:00 pm.

4gnA3lBOuFKL6a9aAZ0knA.text: 4 stars due to pending liquor license. I was looking forward to my Sake after dinner. BUT, the spicy miso Shabu Shabu hit the spot this fine evening. Note to self Cut the cabbage

XwWwPGPykvVqXbUprkqCuQ.text: Tried this place out for the first time yesterday and now I'm obsessed! I love shabu shabu but most places don't have flavor. The menu here is so vast and the food is so flavorful! It comes with different dipping sauces that our server Carl explained so well to us. I ordered the spicy miso and the broth was so good, I didn't always need to dip it in the other sauces. Aside from the amazing food, the vibe there is awesome! The workers make you feel so welcome and the owner Anton even came out to help serve and speak to guest which is really rare at other restaurants. I will definitely become a regular here :)

Tv1WF5_-JTICGdvzcDGKNg.text: Yesterday, we tried this restaurant since it has good reviews on yelp.... for me, first impression is really important. Like, is the restaurant clean and are the people accommodating, etc.... when we first came into the door, the tables were dirty... and i would understand that they haven't cleaned it due to high volume of customers. But there were like 4 customers eating at that time. We stood there without anyone asking us to be seated (and theres a sign that says wait to be seated). So we let that go and finally,  the girl who guided us to our table. She asked us if it was our first time there and we said yes... we were assuming that she would tell us about their menu but she didnt.... it took forever for our orders and the people who were working there were very loud that made us uncomfortable. The food was not bad but was not that great either. We said we will not come back to that restaurant again...

Yvx_3XhfUpFMR1BupgxNWQ.text: I was reading through the reviews and people were complaining about the price. It really isn't expensive compared to other Shabu places I've been to. There are plenty that will cost you $50+ to get the same amount of food as their geisha size. Just saying. I've been a fan of Yojie since I lived in CA - it was also the less expensive of the choices for shabu. I must say this location out does itself. From decorations to menu to even the restrooms. Yes I am loving the restroom. Concrete walls! So modern. Waterfall sink. ooo fancy Menu definitely is bigger here than the CA locations. The Salmon tho!!! You have to try it. I MEAN IT. TRY THE SALMON!!! It is sashimi grade so you can eat it raw and I sure did eat that thing raw. With or without the sauce. I drool just thinking about it. For all you cheapskates out there, get the combo plates, you get more meat that way. And if you didn't know rice and sauce come with refills. That's right FREE REFILLS ON RICE AND SAUCES. Or you can take your cheap butt to melting pot and let see you say yojie is expensive after.

WZYgNZkMfC2RifxqusBBlA.text: Omg this place is sooo good atmosphere is over the top amazing the servers are so friendly they treat you as if your one of there good friends and food are soooooo mind blowingly good. Sokiyaki sauce is so good with pork belly. Really fun amazing experience and delicious food. Price are not bad as well so amazing definatly gona keep on coming back!!

tN0qsR6YRqVAgsYNLLA1pg.text: Yojie is easily one of my favorite local eats! I highly suggest getting the combo plate as it is very filling and you get to pick two different options. I got mine with chicken and beef with the sukiyaki sauce and boy oh boy was I blown away!!! The sauce was sweet but savory and paired well with both meats. They give you an array of vegetables, noodles and choice of rice with every pot! I surprisingly saved room for desert and got the dark chocolate fondue with strawberries and bananas! You won't go wrong with choosing Yojie!

JCBOw1VZmIGVW9MjJMs4TQ.text: Took the kids here for dinner. It opened 2 weeks prior for the decor was modern and trendy as well as clean. We had the prime rib in both sukiyaki and shabu shabu the meat and vegetables were fresh. All the sauces were standard nothing extraordinary. The rice was hard so it was probably left out before being served but it wasn't cheap rice. I was happy that they didn't try to put their own spin on the dish and try to make it some type of" fusion" restaurant. Service was good. We order Extra udon noodles and edamame which never came but it worked out since I ordered too much food anyway. I recommend it anytime you are looking for a healthy meal.

r1-ZbaK4U_Hj6PZARh7Ifw.text: HANDS DOWN one of the COOLEST places here in Las Vegas!  A hidden gem.  My friends and I went here last night for Valentine's Day.  We weren't sure what to expect at all.  They put out the "first timers" block so that the staff could explain everything.  The service was OUTSTANDING!  While we were waiting for some spots to clear up, Anton greeted us personally and asked if he could get us anything to drink while we waited.  He came out with some really nice sparkling sake.  The food was amazing as well!  Once explained, then menu really easy to understand.  We also indulged in the dark chocolate and green tea chocolate fondue for dessert.  Save room for that!  Did I mention they also had a crazy good Pandora playlist going on?!  My group and I were eating it up.  Thanks to Azi (spelling?) and Vhalery, our servers who were so patient and laughed at all our jokes.  You guys are the bomb!  Please visit this place the next chance you get.  You won't regret it!

-ua-Fxx0PS2-AsaVqXp2_g.text: Decor was nice. Food was pretty good, but not amazing. Prices a little high.

6dAhVuciWmgvhZwgvt5sSQ.text: Don't miss dessert- amazing green tea white chocolate fondue & our entrees were great too! Can't wait until they get their liquor license. :-)  The music was too loud for comfortable conversation and didn't fit the restaurant.

mwXcgLequA10RnN5Tg5X7g.text: We had a great time on a double date here. It was our second time here and it was just as delicious and fun. Each person gets their own hot pot cooker with a plate of shaved meat and a bowl of vegetables and noodles.  You swish the meat and veggies in the broth for 30 seconds, dip in the sauce of your choice and eat with rice. Having an activity go with your meal is great when you may not have much to chat about with your dinner mates. I had the yojie's cut steak in the geisha size. Its just right for one person. The meats, veggies, noodles and rice were delicious. They just got their liquor license and have sake cocktails. The matcha green tea fondue was yummy also.

Utor7bS1vUNADHq89IZzRw.text: Friggin' delicious!  My GF and I both love this place.  Must eat there more!  I usually go for the tonkotsu.

DNUaTyEssXAhvVVX4P6kAQ.text: Was so good and a cute-small japanese hot-pot spot! The only reason I didn't give 5 stars is because we were there and sitting by the seats by the front door and people kept coming in and out and the freezing cold air kept interrupting our meal and made us cold and uncomfortable. I would go back but not accept a seat that is near the front. They also didn't serve any alcoholic beverages which was interesting because they had it on their menu :/

T7dKpg7b1sawmerQCHlVJA.text: Great experience and terrific service. Nice spin on traditional shabu shabu. My wife enjoyed the miso broth and I was a huge fan of the sukiyaki. YsKooZg-NeCOJLsV6JZATQ.text: Tasty, fun and healthy. Fits for kids as well (as long as you help out). Price is reasonable and service is good.

DX_on7_wUttzlBClzZIu3Q.text: Once again, I've come here and was not disappointed! From the accommodating and friendly staff to the timely manner the food came out, everything was wonderful.  I always come back to the prime rib with the Sukiyaki dip and it always hits the craving. The beef is tender and the Sukiyaki is the perfect combination of sweetness and saltiness that accentuates the natural flavors of the beef. Boiling the udon noodles in the Sukiyaki is wonderful as well, as the noodles soaks up the flavors of the broth.   This time around, I tried the Green Tea White Chocolate fondue with fruits and pastries. The white chocolate is a bit sweet, but the tartness of the strawberries and the subtle sweetness of the bananas are a good contrast to the chocolate. It is also accompanied by homemade marshmallows that are perfectly fluffy and surprisingly not too sweet. Everyone should try their fondue at least once!

2uhZRWoTmrwknN62pW7A8g.text: Great flavor! Eat the soup and you'll leave a comedian. Something had to be in it because we're still laughing.  -Arigato!!

W43kddGbELQZWov6D-JK7Q.text: They denied us service when they were still open, lazy unmotivated workers that don't want to serve. Currently it is 9:23 and they close at 10. They obviously saw my friend and I at the door and they hid from us. They kept on peaking out to see if we were there, especially the girl in the pink hair. It would have been nice if they at least acknowledged us and told us they weren't serving instead of actively ignoring us. Yojie just needs to keep their lazy workers in check or change the time they close if the workers can't take it.

l5gYJphYCmE9V7Gr2VzwtA.text: If I could eat here once a week, I would. The only thing that is keeping me from doing that is that I live a bit far from it. Literally the best shabu shabu that I've had in the Las Vegas area.  I got the sukiyaki with the size large (samurai) yojie cut. The meat quality is good; they kind of cut it so thin that when i was picking up the uncooked meat with my chopsticks to place it into my pot, sometimes they would rip, which was a little annoying. The flavor of the broth made up for it though!  I asked our incredible server Tai (Thai? I'm sorry I'm not sure how to spell his name!) for some hot drops, which are basically a staple at shabu shabu joints, and he brought me out a bottle that literally was labeled "hot drops." It's actually like a hot sauce paste (and wasn't really that spicy). If you like spicy, I recommend adding more than normal.

803NCx5yItUm5ARSr_475A.text: Yojie is simply amazing every time I come here. It's a Japanese hot pot that you cook your meat and veggies in the broth of your choice. You pick the meat you want and the broth. I always get the yojie's cut of meat with sukiyaki. I've tried the miso, which is good as well but I prefer the sukiyaki broth. The meat is  thinly sliced for quick cooking in the broth.   The sukiyaki comes with a raw egg that you dip your meat into. Sounds kind of weird and maybe gross.. But it's absolutely delicious and a must try.   The veggies they give you are cabbage slices (which are huge and kinda wish they had it chopped), carrots, tofu, seaweed, udon noodles, mushroom, and clear noodles. You can toss the veggies in little by little as you eat or toss it all in.   If you're a spicy food fanatic, ask for their hot chili paste. Beware it's super super spicy. Just add little by little to your broth or put some on your plate to dip a little with your meat and veggies. But the chili paste puts that icing on the cake to the meal.   If you're a first timer also, they give you a little wood block that says first time. So if you don't know what you're doing, they will help you and explain to you the process.   For dessert, I had the berries and bananas fondue with dark chocolate. It's probably good for 2 people after the meal. But that was delicious as well. It came with strawberries and bananas!   You can never go wrong with this place!

photos.caption: Photo of Yojié Japanese Fondue - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Berries and banana fondue with dark chocolate

rZhjxhddUOY6hnDNfEA0JA.text: Fantastic, great staff, over the top food quality, fun shabu shabu dining experience (which in its self is fun) I had the Kobe beef plate, left over full.  Price was one of the lowest cost during our stay in Vegas.  Decided to try since it is co-owned by Jo Koy our favorite comedian.  But left a fan of the restaurant as well

KIVWbslkbcUUYEz72YXn4g.text: Decided to update my review after my recent visit, and also after reading some of the other reviews.   First up....they finally got their LIQUOR LICENSE!!! Woohoo...now you can enjoy a frosty beer or a nice sake with your meal. I guess they got it about 8 months ago.  I went with my friend on a Tuesday night around 7:30 pm. We were promptly greeted and told it would be a minute or two until seated, which was accurate. We were seated next to a group of newbies. My friend had never been to shabu shabu, so I placed our orders. The waiter took his time to describe the meal and help the group next to us cook, which helped my friend. Excellent service!  Unfortunately they had just run out of Kurobota pork which I was planning on getting, so I just went with the Yojie cut. I did not notice any reduction in the quality of the meat. Normally I always get the combo, but I wasn't super hungry and just went with the smaller portion which was just the right amount. My friend loved her food, and finished it all and proclaimed she was stuffed!! So no dessert, which the group next to us did order and the fruit with chocolate fondue looked so gooooooooood I wanted some.  I've eaten here at least 8 times since they've opened, and it is one of my favorite places in Las Vegas to eat, and easily the best Shabu-Shabu place. I've never had bad service, and the food has always been great.

QjRsc4KG2nETSUk-21elBw.text: I have been to this location several times, and I have hesitated to write a review because the service was so lacking and mediocre. I was impressed with the 3 servers working during my last visit, I think our primary server was Shannon. Each were complimentary and collaborating to make the dining experience for all of the customers fantastic. The overall experience was greater than 5 stars.  The food has always been fresh and the dessert platter - although needing more chocolate sauce - was fantastic.   I hope that they continue on this path of collaborative service!

photos.caption: Photo of Yojié Japanese Fondue - Las Vegas, NV, United States

MPUHa-uwDVa9hiZDMsu_UQ.text: Wowwww I've been to loads of Japanese fondue places but this one was by far the best I've ever had. All the broths they had are AMAZING and definitely added flavor to their high quality meats! They give you a bunch of vegetable as well. Rice and veggies are unlimited and comes with the whole thing! The vibe here is great and they played some good music that my friends and I jammed out to while eating! It's such a chill spot and the staff were so friendly and attentive! Definitely coming back to this place soon! Definitely a favorite

Yn4Y0eobvNrGuVihuV0sPQ.text: I LOVEEEE Yojie!! I eat here often becuase I feel so satisfied after. The waiters and waitresses are super friendly and are on top of taking care of customers. Love the R&B music too.

yum6wpIVVitYCi5-Zfzn4Q.text: Best shabu shabu in LV (and maybe anywhere) hands down!  If you're looking for the same style of shabu shabu that you would find in California (e.g. Shabuway, California Shabu Shabu, among others), you will find it at Yojie. According to their website they have 4 California locations and this one location in LV.   The ordering process is simple, and similar to other shabu shabu places. First, choose your size and type of protein. I recommend going with the samurai (7 oz) portion if you are hungry. We've normally gone with the Yojie's cut beef, which has been well marbled and a great cut. Then, choose your broth. I recommend the spicy miso! Really flavorful and delicious.  One thing that sets Yojie apart is that they offer chocolate fondue for dessert. The green tea white chocolate fondue is absolutely to die for, and will keep me coming back!

mCo-80vJDPivh40nIGcfsw.text: First time here and the vibe is great! Best music selection ever!!! Food was good and options are plenty! The service is the main reason I couldn't give 5 stars.   We went on a Monday night and were sat immediately. 3 in our party and my daughter and I chose to share the XL portion. The wait time for the food was average. The issue was the waitress kept forgetting things and getting her attention took forever. I asked 3 times for a fork for my daughter because they never brought out ladles or tongs. Getting refills on tea and rice were also difficult and the temperature on the burner needed to be adjusted but again, no waitress to ask to help.  I will say the clean up between dinner and dessert was prompt and so was paying the check when we left.  I give 3 stars for the food and 1 for the super cool teapot and the atmosphere.  The food and ambiance was worth the slow/poor service and I will give them another chance. I hope they step it up in the service area though...

hO88OCyXrAIvSY7cFLYNIA.text: This place makes my top 5 favorite restaurants in Las Vegas. Location is far from my home but every time I get the chance to drive up to Summerlin I make sure to stop by. Only thing I do not like is that they close in between lunch and dinner. I've came before and we had to wait a whole hour until dinner started in order to dine in (super annoying!).   Place is pretty cool, lots of local art on the walls (love seeing my friends art up there). Very clean and bright with a choice of sitting on high or low bar. We always choose low bar, for some reason we do not like the high bar.  My go to is always the "Chicken Breast, in Sukiyaki, no egg instead I ask for swisher and ponzu sauce, and an extra veggie bowl no udon noodles extra thin ones instead". Ask for their hot sauce it is so good in your broth but be careful, it is really really spicy!!!!!! (use 3-4 drops).   Staff is always super friendly and on their A game. They also have a rewards system that accumulates points but not sure exactly how it works, I just know we have one.

yPIxQBhn0nGBGDWcKAF_bg.text: This was my first hot pot experience and it was absolutely delicious. The staff was super attentive and helpful. We will be coming back for sure!

0U0afn9eSpDItm6U7OhSLg.text: I've been wanting to try this place since I heard about it so I was excited to finally get the chance. (Confession: I'm a big JoKoy fan )  Went on a Monday night and it wasn't busy at all so service was super quick. Server explained the concept well since it was our first time. I chose the Geisha portion of Yojie and it was just perfect! ~$30 (tax+tip included)  I like hot pot/soups in general so this was right up my alley!   Meat was really good quality and the accoutrements were just right! The broth had a nice flavor as well. My friend chose the salmon and it ended over cooking a bit so I recommend if you go with seafood, cooking your fish last or just pouring the cooked accoutrements and broth over it.   Would definitely go back next time I'm in Vegas!

ucL3H6rltV66HF_ygpp53A.text: This shabu shabu spot is cozy and has fabulous service and the food is fantastic.  The vegetables are delicious and crisp the udon and rice compliments the meat perfectly.  I will definitely come back again.

OYfWdfIrRmhK5aVrNaabyg.text: I had heard great things about Yojie so I came for lunch on a saturday. I did not know what to expect as I had never heard of shabu shabu, the restaurant's specialty.  The waitress sat me down at a counter and explained the menu, the sauces, and the cooking process.  After she teaches you it is pretty self explanatory - you simply dip the meat and vegetables into the cooking broth and cook it as long as you want.  You can then even make a soup out of the used broth if you desire.  You also get a few sauces for dipping.  With each shabu shabu meal you are given noodles and vegetables, as well as the chosen meat.  I only had the geisha and was full after eating the entire ensemble.    The meal was delicious, unique, and a must visit if looking for something unique in Las Vegas.  It costs around $15-$20 depending on the meal chosen, so not too expensive.  The seating is at the counter though so it could be a problem if you have a large group, but other than that I recommend this place.  Shabu shabu is one of my new favorite meals.

IktPRhmj8hmgUhiddskAfA.text: Place is very hip. Went here to try out JoKoy's resto. Glad we did. You pick your meat then pick a broth (sukiyaki, spicy miso, tonkotsu or shabu-shabu). We all picked kobe beef which was sliced thinly. The quality of meat is great. I just didn't like to wait for the food to cook. You have to have a lot of time to eat here.

Mb1z_VjesOD7cTiD9N823Q.text: 5/5 food 5/5 service  Yojie serves some of the freshest cuts of meat I have ever had. I had the angus and the salmon, and the salmon was so fresh it could be eaten raw! The ponzu sauce was good with EVERYTHING.  Service was good too, it was my first time here and the server was very helpful in every part of the whole visit! Don't be afraid to ask for questions if it's your first time!  Overall, I really like this place, it has a modern and calm ambiance. Will be coming back!

afcXsN46TkjJ7aWCsfTHmA.text: The best shabu shabu in town.  The experience began with a very clean restaurant and amazingly kind staff, we were seated almost immediately. To our surprise the amazing Jo Koy was at the restaraunt to help greet us. Along with being an amazingly funny comedian, he was also a gracious and entertaining host. The rest of the staff was extraordinarily nice, and any questions or requests we had were answered with a smile  The food was outstanding. My friends and I had the sukiyaki and the spicy miso. The sukiyaki was a lightly sweated, robust teriyaki flavor which fit perfectly with the raw pasturized egg served on the side. The spicy miso was very robust miso soup style taste, however, the sauce was the star of the show. The sauces were a sesame sauce, and the goma sauce. Along with the miso broth, to even out the flavor, it was amazing. The vegetables were fresh and varied,  and tied the meal together.  We finished off the meal with the white chocolate green tea fondue. This was a standard fondue desert, it was absolutely delicious.  The price per plate is about 15 to 25 dollars, this is without alcohol, and for the price, it was amazing.  Thank you Yojie for a wonderful time.

rpyeSNxdbOvS0x-eIydJoQ.text: Took the little brother here since he wanted to try Shabu Shabu. LOL. I didn't have a clue what he was talking about when he asked, but hey... The kid wanted to go there, so we went.  We were greeted and seated right away by a friendly face. I liked how it was clean, modernly designed and not crowded. The waitress gave us a few minutes to look over the menu. She could tell we were new, so when taking our orders, she gave us a few recommendations that we might like. Quite knowledgeable about their menu.  The nice part is when she walked us through how to eat the dishes properly, instead of letting us act all crazy and just put everything in the hot pot. LOL. I bet that would've been hilarious, but man... I certainly would've felt dumb.  It was cool of her to check up on the brother, making sure he had enough broth in the pot for the entire meal. She'd also turn the little stove area down notches once in awhile to keep the stuff from boiling. At the end of the meal, she put our stuff together to bring home, which was pretty much the fixings of udon.  I had the Samurai portion of the Prime Rib with Spicy Miso, Brown Rice, Ponzu and the Swisher Sauces. The brother had Pork Combo Plate (also comes with Yojie Cut Angus Beef) with Sukiyaki, Pasteurized Egg and White Rice. I like me some Prime Rib, but I wish I had ordered what my brother got. The pork just went so well with the broth, then dipping it into the egg. For dessert, we both had the Ramune Float. Yummy citrus sweetness. Apparently the brother will be copying that dessert for home.  All in all, if the brother gave me a happy face and said he liked the place for food and customer service, we'll be going back whenever we're in the area.

6i7-ICKQCFkc5u6U4t-dsg.text: So good that I had to "try" this place two nights in a row.  The quality of the meats is where it's at. Both times I had the Geisha sized Yojie cut which was the perfect amount of food, although I could probably eat more if famished.  It was an especially hot/humid Vegas night, which made the fully packed restaurant pretty hot. Would be cool to try this place during winter.

wIUq9tlqx_-KIkkRHO9pLA.text: First time ever at Yojie the service was so amazing that I contemplated bringing my resume and working there. Friendly, attentive, staff fully understands the menu, and always presented neatly. The service is just a feature of its polished product. The neatly placed vegetables or equal positioned layers of meat on the plate will bring smiles to any OCD freaks.   From some perspectives the single digit quantity of meat may not seem like much, but Japanese hot pot (or any hot pot for that matter) is a long meal, providing satisfaction over a period of working time, allowing you to enjoy each bite you prepared for yourself. Your patience might be tested though as there is usually a line, and unconventional seating along an counter (sort of hinders group conversations, so avoid for double dates/meeting the folks)  Favorites include the Yojie's cut, prime rib, pork belly, Arnold Palmer-San (refills included), and the green tea fondue.

eH1aHpnt7WakI03FtZODFg.text: Our family frequents several of the restaurants in this plaza, and Yojie has been on our radar for some time.  It's cool looking, sleek decor... and my favorite comedian (Jo Koy) apparently owns it.  Last night was a cold night, so we decided to try it out.   A cold Friday night... I figured it would be packed.  Well it was about 1/2 full when we got there for dinner.  Always a suspicious sign.  We sat down on the lower counter.   Servers were super friendly.  I like that.  She walked us through the menu and knew what we wanted.    Wife order the prime rib.  My 8-yr old ordered he sashimi salmon.  I ordered the Angus.   The WORST part of this concept... they upcharge EVERYTHING!!  $2 extra for this, $1 for that, $3 of this.   Just charge $35-$39 per person and include it.  Do you really need to charge for 2-3 leaves of cabbage?  The only soup broth that is free is the original shabu shabu.  I guess water and a little piece of seaweed.  lol.  Wtf?!    Perhaps this is keeping to the traditions, but who really cares?!  Jo Koy isn't even Japanese!   lol.   They charge extra if you want a flavored broth.  And don't forget, you only get two dipping sauces.  If you want the third, yep... you guessed it, you'll have to pay.    A meal for two adults and an 8 yr old was $150 with tip.     I promise, if they charge $35 per entree, the place would have a line out the door and the bill would be the same.  I doubt we will be back.  There just wasn't anything that we loved.   We liked a lot of it, but nothing that we woke up craving.

xGW_Q6Bvs4COdkoN0LmUmg.text: Anton and his crew always go above and beyond...customer service is excellent. Food  always hits the spot! I've had the yojie cut and pork belly...can't wait to try the others. The green tea fondue is heaven. I've been there three times and looking forward to the next one real soon.

-0ybXCDESPpCdYErwOr-Kg.text: My second time here and I'm still impressed. They are so friendly and the food is great. LOVE the spicy miso broth. Ponzu and Goma are the best sauces for this broth. As a female I find that the Geisha portions are perfect for dinner. You get the vegetables, noodles and rice so that fills you up as well (plus you can save room for dessert). Prices are reasonable if you stay away from the Kobe and Wagyu ($79 sometimes). Kurobuta Pork is excellent. For 4 of us the meal was $100 so I don't that that's too bad. I like the interactive cooking, I just wish the tables were designed to be a little more interactive with your party. (It's ok if there's 2-3 of you but any more and it's tough to include everyone in the conversation). Healthy eating!

3ObI2nivosoyEcfQcLh7vA.text: Been a fan ever since I first discovered them in LA.  For me, it's a very clean shabu shabu and is the closet one that I've been able to find to my absolute favorite in So Cal, California Shabu Shabu.    My only critique is that they have not started their Swisher Society program and they always #-ing their Instagram posts with #SwisherSociety when they don't have it up and running yet.  Every time I inquire about it, I'm told they are aiming to get the system up by the end of the month.  I've been going about twice a month since their soft opening in late May.  Also, they do not have their liquor license yet.  I am not a huge drinker but I would think a business that has been open for that long would have been able to finalize their liquor license closer to it's opening date.  I gave them 4 of 5 starts for these two issue and would gladly give them 5 once those issues are resolved.  Update 10/28: Still waiting for Swisher Society to be accepted here and still waiting for the liquor license... not sure if they're even going to bother with either anymore....

4nnrbAK4hilpKCyFtFpIiw.text: Epic #AfterSEMA Day 2 Dinner at @jokoy's @yojielv Japanese Fondue. It was a cold and rainy evening and we decided to get shabu shabu for dinner. SQLBNNTe5x9RhdYP0S_qmQ.text: I have always wanted to try Shabu, Shabu (Swish, Swish) from Japan. What is Shabu,Shabu you ask?? According to their website, it is "The Art of Dipping" We arrived around 7:00pm on a Saturday evening. The restaurant is in a "U" shape with a choice of sitting on a high top or a low counter level. We opted for the high top. Glad we arrived when we did because in fifteen minutes, every seat was taken in the restaurant. This was reassuring since we had never been here before. They have comfortable bar stools to sit on and the restaurant is very clean. In front of each seat, there is a burner along with plenty of counter space to hold all of your food. First you have to choose your plate, they offer three types of beef including Kobe, Angus and Japanese Wagyu. There is also prime rib, chicken, pork, pork belly, salmon and a veggie medley. Next you choose your dip or broth. Your choices are shabu shabu (water based and the healthiest), Sukiyaki with a pasteurized egg for additional dipping, spicy miso, and a pork tonkotsu. Each entree comes with a bowl of vegetables, noodles, and your choice of white or brown rice. I chose the chicken with the Sukiyaki and egg and my husband had the Japanese Wagyu beef with the tonkotsu sauce. Right after we placed the order, our server came out with a Japanese gong and asked me to "Bang A Gong" since we had ordered the Wagyu beef. When the check came, I knew why...This was pretty fun and when I did bang the gong, the whole kitchen cheered and again when the check came, I knew why. Wagyu beef is pricey! The servers are really friendly and they thoroughly explained the whole process from cooking the meat and vegetables to how to enjoy the meal. We were definitely in "virgin territory" but we both jumped into this new experience. The food comes out all at once with your big bowl of veggies and noodles, the broth and the meat. We were advised to shabu, shabu our meat anywhere from 15-20 seconds. I went about 25 seconds just to make sure that it was cooked. WOW! The flavors that came from the combo of the sauce and then dipping the meat in the egg was incredible. I could not believe all the flavor the little egg provided! Our server told me for a first time customer, I was brave in my choice of broth in terms of taste. I would choose that same sauce and egg again. I really enjoyed the rich taste of the combo. The vegetables included cabbage, mushrooms, carrots, watercress and then there were some noodles. You can make the decision whether or not you wish to enjoy your veggies crunchy or you can cook them too. My husband shared his Wagyu beef with me which had a sweet and delicate flavor well marbled and delicious rare.  My chicken was really tasty and fresh.  We had plans with some friends so we were unable to try out the dessert which is a great reason to return. When we left, we did not feel bloated or full like you do after a big meal. We both felt really energized and healthy. If you are in the neighborhood, be sure to shuffle, shuffle on over and enjoy some Shabu, Shabu!

AIU4ZoskAFr-r1oTd50K8w.text: After getting so disappointed in one of the local hot pot place, I decided to look for alternative, so I decided to give Yojie a try.  I love it, and reasonable priced, great and very attentive service! However, i didn't really appreciate they are telling us we have to sit at certain spot because they anticipate weekend to be busier (there are about 20% empty seat left at that time), after we sat down, all I see is people keeps leaving and had plenty of seat left, if it's a nearly full restaurant, I can understand, but it would be nice if they can think for customer first.  Another star off is the brown rice I have is spoiled, after couple of bite, I start to smell something not right, I smelled it closely and it's in very early stage of spoiling.  Trust me I cooked brown rice all the time and I had several experience of accidentally left it out in my rice cooker overnight during hot summer day and that's exactly the same smell that I'm smelling.  Luckily I didn't get sick, but I can tell because not many people order brown rice, so they just used the old left over rice and didn't realize it had gone bad.  In summary, I will still go back, I love the food and service, but just watch out if you get brown rice, ALWAYS smell it first, if it doesn't smell right, do not eat it and tell them they need to learn how to store the rice properly during summer time

Q0MWoA4885cFwTnmnE1mfg.text: A must try place in Vegas. I ordered combo with pork and yojie beef. It was the best shabu shabu experience ever (given I had plenty in the past). Thinly sliced meat to ensure it can be cooked easily, yet maintaining the tenderness. Broth is rich but not heavy. Unlimited refill of rice (brown or white). Great mix of sauce for the meat. A bowl of mixed veggies and udon was included. Bottom line is, both pork and beef are very tender, good portion, and great combination of food. To top it off, staff was very friendly, passionate and helpful. I would highly recommend this place even if u are just visiting vegas for fun!

WXMnn-XixT9KxOIViyJg6w.text: I came here a few days ago and I wasn't impressed. There was nothing special about the atmosphere nor the food. I sat in the back of the restaurant and it was poorly lit since they depended on the natural sunlight to come in. I ordered the Yojie cut with sukiyaki broth. I was charged $2 extra for this soup which was misleading because I thought the egg was what tagged on the additional dollars and I didn't want the egg. Since I live on the opposite side of town, I would rather go to a shabu shabu restaurant in Chinatown, which is much closer to me, and I get the same food. The pots of broth are just sitting on the shelf, and to me that sounds like an opportunity for bacteria to grow throughout the day since it's not refrigerated. The service wasn't that great either. I think the waitress I had was new since she seemed inexperienced. I also saw her taking selfies behind the register which is very unprofessional.

IlqlztocI8RjG0bUhra3eQ.text: I've never had shabu shabu before, but our meal at Yojie was such a memorable experience! My husband and I went out to eat with a friend who will be moving out of town soon, and I'm so glad that we went to this restaurant because it was such a fun meal that we will remember.  The decor is very nice, and it's obvious that everything about this restaurant was well thought out. The napkins and chopsticks were set out in such a cute way, the bar looked so nice, it was very appealing. I'm glad that we came with a small group because it is a very intimate restaurant with two counters. They were playing hilarious Japanese game shows on the television screens and we enjoyed them.  The food itself was great! Having never tried japanese fondue before I feel uncomfortable giving it a five star rating, but it was probably a 4.5! My husband and I split the largest portion of the house beef, and it was a filling meal. He has tried a lot of subiyaki during a time that he lived in Korea, and insisted that the meal was traditional and great. They do charge 5$ to split an order, but you also get an extra portion of rice, your own pot (so you can choose different broths if you would like) and your own sauces. My husband tried subiyaki and I tried the spicy miso. The miso tasted wonderful but was not as spicy as I would have liked (and I am not very tolerant of hot food)! I added chili sauce, though, and it was just fine. My husband loved the subiyaki, so if you would like a sweet broth, that's the one to pick!  We didn't order any dessert because the meal was so filling, but if we return I would try the white chocolate and green tea fondue.   Overall, I'm really happy that we ate here. This would be a wonderful date night restaurant, we will be back!

n3e5zv-HGiR3F3cOFUL8Ow.text: What a cool urban modern place to eat. Jo Koy is the co-owner of this place and my favorite comedian. He served us our dessert and started eating it which was pretty hilarious and I let him. But overall rating for this place is 9 out of 10. Just a little pricey but definitely a go to place.

39_DLbqRd-_c_Nan4JPYOQ.text: Call me slightly Shabu Shabu obsessed. Went three days in a row of their soft opening but who's keeping track. I could make up random reasons why you shouldn't go here and selfishly keep this spot my little secret but what kind of yelper would I be if I told the yelp community to stay away.  I've had my fair share of LA Shabu Shabu, so I was ecstatic when I found out an LA base franchise Shabu Shabu spot was coming to Vegas. FINALLY I don't have to starve in Vegas and travel great distances when I'm craving shabu shabu.  My go-to order: Kobe Beef or Japanese Wagyu   Sukiyaki dip (comes with pasteurized egg sauce) Add on goma sauce and ponzu sauce.   Meat quality: When in LA I always opt for the meat with the most marbling with high fat content due to the softness of the beef after being swished in boiling delicious sukiyaki. In LA its aka is "Fatty belly" which is Washimi Wagyu beef toro. I would say its closes to their Kobe beef American gold grade BMS 9-12. If you're feeling baller get the Japanese Wagyu BMS 5 it's like butter. If you're confused all Kobe beef is Wagyu, but not all Wagyu is kobe beef. Which I love how Yojie explains on their menu exactly what you're getting. If you like a little bit tender meat can't go wrong with their prime rib or yojie's cut which is a hand selected angus beef cut by chef Yojie.  Veggies:  Shabu Shabu comes with a variety of veggies: Bok choy, carrots, broccoli, onions, cabbage, mushroom and noodles. My only complaint about the vegetables but it's really no big deal. Some veggies come out frozen but it melts anyway. So I suggest don't eat them raw.   Soup base:  You have your choices of four soup dips. ShabuShabu which is your more traditional shabu shabu flavor, its clean and very light. Spicy miso, it's full of flavor and a crowd favorite. Tonkotsu which I haven't tried will update and my personal favorite sukiyaki, a more sweet soy sauce dip.   Sauce: It ain't easy being SAUCY. Actually in this case it is. Depending on your dipping soup. It comes with an assortment of Sauces that compliment your dipping soup. Don't have a panic attack if your favorite sauce isn't included you can always do an add on. I kind of went crazy here. My sukiyaki came with a pasteurized egg sauce that looks a lot like a raw egg. No worries the eggs been pasteurized to reduce food borne-illnesses so dip with no fear! It adds a silky buttery texture to your meat after sukiyaki dipping. My personal favorites are the goma sesame sauce with fine crushed sesame seeds on top and their tangy ponzu sauce. Add Shallots and garlic to taste with Yojie's in house "drop drop drop it likes its hot drop" Caution! Spicy.   Drinks:  First time I came here our server suggested to try their popular green tea with sweetener on the side. I didn't find much of a green tea flavor to this. So I'd personally pass on it next time.   Service:  Impeccable. I have no complaints. The servers are attentive, helpful, and very knowledgeable of the menu. So if you're a first timer don't panic. They got you covered on the how-to's.   Tips: - Ask for Yojie's in-house drop drop drop it like its hot drop to add a kick to your dipping sauces (beware its concentrated, adjust to your spicy tolerance). - Save your noodles and some veggies to the end. You can opt for your server to make udon noodle soup with your dip base that you can take to go.  - Ask for the manager Mika she's the best!  - Ask for Anna or Denise. Excellent service!

oxott2soRkrSjoVxq2P20A.text: I normally prefer chinese hot pot over japanese shabu shabu, but this place is unique.  I would say this place is hipster/ trendy, clean, pristine, and they have anime playing on TV (Samurai Shampoo to be exact).    Broths: I got the tonkatsu broth, which includes two sauces - Goma and Ponzu.  The server added a few extra seasonings to my sauces (I can't remember everything he put in there, but I do remember chilli oil and sesame seeds).  My brother got the spicy miso broth and that was full of flavor.  I've been to other shabu shabu places, and I've never had broth like this.  I ordered the Yojie's Cut dinner Sumo size (10oz of beef).  This comes with rice, veggies, and noodles.  The 10oz was super filling, but it was so good that I wanted more!  I like the presentation of the beef and veggies.    For dessert, we ordered the strawberry and bananas fondue with green tea white chocolate.  I'm not typically a fan of green tea chocolate, but I was mind blown with the flavor.  It was shared with 6 people, so it didn't go to waste.  Typically, this dessert can be shared with 2-3 people.    Also, I had the cherry blossom hot tea.  It was interesting to see it served in a tea infuser.  Overall I had a really good experience (and more so hooked) to this place.

c7QtVbM6Mkni2mJKODeUmw.text: I was ecstatic to hear that a new shabu shabu place opened up near my work. Fun fact- The co-owner is comedian Jo Koy. This sleek and modern restaurant seats around 30 people? The employees here are friendly and will explain everything if you have never been here or if you are a shabu shabu noob. Service was very attentive. You can tell they just opened and wanted to make sure they were explaining everything and being very helpful. There are cute Asian girls working here too. ;)  So this is how you order. First you pick one of four different serving sizes - 3 oz (kodomo), 5 oz (geisha), 8 oz (samurai), or 12 oz (sumo). I thought the descriptions for the servings sizes were cute. Next, you pick your choice of meat (Angus cut, prime ribeye, Kobe beef), chicken, pork, salmon, combo, or vegetarian. Then you pick your broth- shabu shabu, sukiyaki, or spicy miso. It comes with white or brown rice, veggies (cabbage, broccoli, shiitake, carrots), udon, glass noodles, and dipping sauces.  I opted for Yojie's cut with sukiyaki with egg dip which is $2 additional. I went with the geisha size. The eggs are pasteurized at 140 degrees if you're worried about salmonella. The Angus meat had good marbling compared to the other shabu shabu places that I have been to in Vegas. You can add additional sides or more meat for you sumos.  I will be back and will try the shabu shabu and go for sumo size because I'm a meat fatty and 5 oz wasn't enough. Lastly, I have to mention the hot plates were far or maybe I'm short so I made a mess (sorry!) so be wary of that for you short people.

MJgB6XlXz5nrGIUcMADpog.text: This place has healthy food. They have 4 different sauces to choose from, and the basic one has no flavor at all. I highly recommend this for those who want to eat plain without sugars added. Server was very energetic and kind.

BMcvufZGYQdfoexdi1ydOw.text: I recommend their sukiyaki and comes along with a variety of veggies, noodles and meats.

gYUpoLMQnByndod3bT3hPQ.text: The Skinny: although the quality of product is okay, meager portions for the price. The flavor of the broth/sauce is alright. (3) service: ambience is modern, service was okay but easily overwhelmed (3), value: for all its nickel and dime tactics,  the value just isn't there. If you must try this place,  come for lunch. They charge extra for dinner without adding any value(3).  FYI - Yojie is located close to Tropical Smoothie cafe and Viva Mercado's.   Walking into the restaurant,  there were 2 guests in eating lunch at around 11:30 am. You are required to sign in even though there is no wait. It was weird because it took a few minutes for anyone to notice we came in.   Regardless we were seated promptly and the menu was explained to us. They have quite a few options of meat but the pricing is based on the size of your protein portion. For most things on the the menu,  sizes were only 5oz (geisha) and 7oz (samurai). Only the Yojie cut had 4 sizing options (3 oz, 5 oz, 7oz, 10oz). This comes with white/brown rice and a bowl of vegetables/noodles.  Kombu broth (water/seaweed) is standard but they charge extra for sukiyaki, spicy miso, or tonkotsu broth ($2/$2/$3 respectively). Sukiyaki comes with an egg while the other broths come with 2 out of 3 dipping sauces which are ponzu, goma (sesame), and their sweet and savory (apparently a ginger teriyaki sauce). Extra sauce,  rice, veggies cost extra.   We ordered the Yojie cut (Sumo sized, $20.99 lunch) and a kurobuta pork(Samurai sized, $17.99) with spicy miso and tonkotsu broth.   The Yojie cut had medium marbling. I was unimpressed that they left a really huge chunk of fat at the end of the pieces of meat (I understand they can't control the huge chunk of fat in the middle). If you are paying by weight, the meat needs to be properly trimmed. The kurobuta pork tasted good but was really fatty as well.   The spicy miso broth and tonkotsu broth (made with alkaline water!... Sorry for the bit of sarcasm) were both okay but it doesn't compare to any half decent ramen joint in terms of flavor even after all the cooking is done. Not worth the premium.   Tried the goma and ponzu and was not impressed.The goma (sesame sauce) was a bit too earthy (can't think of another word for this) for my tastes. The ponzu lacked the True citrus flavor and acidity of yuzu which made it rather pedestrian.   The side of rice and vegetables were really disappointing in portion size. The vegetable bowl looks pretty but there really isn't alot in there. In total: half a slice of onion, 2 small Napa cabbage leaves cut into 4,  4 spinach leaves, half of a small carrot,  1 shitake mushroom,  1 mouth sized amount of enoki, 2 small pieces of broccoli, 2 bite size pieces of tofu,  4 udon noodles and 5 pieces of rice noodles. Oh, and a small bite of pickled daikon and seaweed thrown in there.   They also only give about a half bowl of rice.   Service was very attentive at the beginning when there were only 2 people other than us in the joint. However once there were 6 people in the restaurant,  service became spotty with water refills. And this is when there were at least 2 servers for the restaurant!   Ambience is modern, hipster and ventilation is good but makes it difficult to hear with the music in the background.   Our total for this lunch for 2 was $48 with tax with no drinks or dessert. The food is okay in my books and I have definitely had better. Considering portion sizing, taste, and level of service,  the prices are exorbitant. Given the premium they charge for dinner (for no reason!),  it becomes even more insane. Pass on this place (3 starred review).

2ggumbUidi346wV2xaBljA.text: I love this restaurant and the restaurant is conveniently down the street from my house.  I'm almost embarrassed to say how often I go here.   Their meats come in different sizes (oz) and their broth come in 4 different types & dipping styles.  I usually get the combo plate which is 5oz of the yojie's cut and 5oz of another meat your choice.  Typically I get pork belly or salmon.  I always get sukiyaki with the pasteurized egg and a side of Gina sauce.   If you get sukiyaki don't get thrown off about dipping cooked meat into what looks like a raw egg.. It's a game changer.  It makes the bite more buttery and it doesn't add strong egg flavor to it.  Their iced green tea is light and you can get simple syrup to sweeten it up or you could get it mixed with lemonade for added sweetness.  Everyone that works here is really friendly and we've seen Jo Koy here a couple times which is pretty cool.  This place won't disappoint you!

YDUstf_xL6zCs_F5y5FzvQ.text: My first shabu shabu experience was at the Yojie Artesia location while visiting Cali cousins and it was AMAAAAZING. I had such a wonderful dining experience and when I heard they were opening a Las Vegas location, I freaked out from excitement!  The overall experience was the same-- a U-shaped bar if you're trying shabu shabu or sukiyaki and some non-bar tables for other food items. The menu looked slightly different. There were some new items (Wagyu, Pork Belly, Swisher sauce, etc) that I didn't see at the Artesia location and also, the prices were higher. Then again, Vegas is always expensive so I wasn't entirely shocked.  I always opt for Samurai Yojie's Cut Shabu Shabu. 7 oz. of delicious meat, although I think I could still kill the Sumo (10 oz.) if I'm a hungry hippo. It comes with the sliced meat, brown or white rice, assorted fresh vegetables, broth, tofu, noodles & 2 sauces (Goma is life!). Swish swish and cook that meat, dip them in your sauces & devour them along with your veggies as you wish. Service is excellent so make sure to ask to customize your overall meal with various seasonings if you love it spicy.  Even with all the food, my friend & I had room for dessert & we ordered the Green Tea White Chocolate with Strawberries and Banana. I almost licked the bowl clean; it was that good. My palate was as happy as my belly. It was a good ending to a yummy meal.  Yojie is a little pricey but the excellent customer service, friendly ambiance, delicious food are worth it. This place is all in all just good vibes! And you never know, you might be able to meet the co-owner, the ever hilarious comedian Jo Koy while dining there. ;)

jNt2M9Gs6o2CUaUA7Kx95A.text: This place is just ok. Broths don't taste right but the quality if the meats are good. A little over priced.

zhYAgdHhEaNuQYyQcZVLSA.text: 3.7865 stars   I honestly wasn't a fan here. Maybe that's why I never tried the DTLA location. The portions of everything were so tiny I had to eat off left overs from my friend's portion. Best part about eating this place was meeting Philip T!   This shabu place is set up as a bar and I didn't like it. Maybe also I like family style hot pot? I guess this is the hip new modern shabu shabu.   The customer service was great and attentive but a little smothering. I understand that it's a soft opening but being asked how's the food every 10 minutes does get too much. I really did like how the waitress went through the whole entire menu with us since we're first timers at Yojie.   I ordered the sukiyaki with pasteurized egg with the Yojie cut geisha size. The broth was honestly way too sweet for my taste. They even diluted it water. I really did like the egg with all the condiments mixed in with it!  I wish I order the spicy miso like Jen Z. ! Her broth was much more savory and rich than mine. I had to switch with her after her meal. The portions of everything was very small. I pretty much ate everything of mine and finished off all of Jen Z's veggies and noodles to feel full. The quality of the meats were superb and fresh!   I'm really glad I got to finally try out this place maybe I'll check out the LA location for the family style shabu shabu.

photos.caption: Photo of Yojié Japanese Fondue - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Yojie cut geisha size

nPvPXLkfIMYoZwkPLu0abw.text: Okay, a little perspective here. I have had shabu shabu in several different cities around the world and each experience had its own distinction. Yojie falls into my trendy category. It's new, it's modern and from the other reviews I have read, it mildly rubs the traditionalists the wrong way. Good. I don't want to have the same thing I have everywhere else.  I like the bar setup. I like the individual pots. I don't have to worry that my DH can't have seafood because I have an allergy. Furthermore, I don't have to squabble with him over the last piece of tofu in the pot. "Was that yours?" "No, it's mine." I take food grudges very seriously.  I do have to admit that I was not familiar with all of the vegetables provided. I did wish there was more tofu and carrots. The meat (I had beef) was sliced perfectly, however it could have been in slightly shorter pieces. The Sumo portion is 10 oz. and id regarded as XL, it was what I considered a regular portion. The goma (sesame) sauce was delicious. The only real complaint I had were technical difficulties. I didn't have a plate to put my cooked meat on and there was no skimmer to clear the water. In spite of that, the restaurant is clean tending toward spartan.  Now, I will forever love my regular shabu shabu restaurant in Green Valley, but I see myself coming to Yojie quite often. One of the main reasons being that is much closer to my area of town (only a few miles closer but far more convenient).  The service was prompt and pleasant, the servers as far as I could see were delightfully polite and attentive.

u0J3XI6_dajv_TLQDuzcQg.text: Really used to enjoy this place until about a month ago when they reduced the quality of the beef by about two grades. A bad move when you consider that they just jacked their prices.  I let them know my dissatisfaction but decided to give them another chance tonight and found that it has gotten worse.  We had this server with purple hair who was clueless.  Found out that they had run out of both cuts of meat that my wife and I wanted.  On top of that, they really short-changed me by giving me only 1/4 of a small mushroom and a few strands of glass noodles to put in the broth.  We called a more senior server over and she got me fixed up but I don't like to have to keep complaining to get what I paid for.  We gave them a second chance but now I think of that old adage: "Fool me one time, shame on you.  Fool me two times, shame on me"  I have a sense that they are not surviving well (mismanaged) and probably won't be around much longer.  So sad, it used to be pretty good, albeit overpriced.

DP3EktexaMJDebJNpX5sIA.text: We came here with another couple after a movie at Village Square theater. The restaurant is just across the parking lot, so we didn't even have to move the car. The restaurant is fairly small and dominated by a horseshoe shaped counter, with the servers in the center. All seating is at the counter. Each place setting has a "burner" where the bowl heating the liquid to cook your food is placed. This was our first experience with shabu-shabu dining. Carl, our main server, came over immediately and explained the dining experience we were about to have. My wife and I opted to share the combo plate with Angus beef and salmon ($5 surcharge for sharing but they give you lots of extras - so very worth it). Our friends shared the chicken and Angus beef combo. That way we each got to sample the beef, chicken and salmon - a highly recommended strategy for other first timers. I chose to cook in spicy miso while my wife chose alkaline water/seaweed broth. In addition to the meats, they serve a large portion of fresh veggies (cabbage, carrots, broccoli, and more), tofu and noodles, also to be cooked at the table. After you cook your food, you can dip it in one of 3 dipping sauces - Goma (a sesame base), Ponzu (citrus soy), or Swisher (sweet and savory). The meal includes a good sized bowl of either brown or white rice. The salmon was sashimi grade so it could be eaten without cooking. I had some of mine that way. Very fresh tasting and flavorful. The beef was sliced incredibly thin so it cooked really fast. Also delicious. As was the chicken. Anton, the owner, came over during the meal to make sure everything was going well. He is very personable and answered any of our remaining questions.  Excellent food, service and ambiance. Who knew cooking your own dinner in a restaurant could be that much fun. The only negative is that there is only counter seating, so it is difficult to be social when you are a party of 4 or more. Also, the restaurant is fairly new so they don't have a liquor license yet, so no beer or wine with the meal. I am sure they will have it when we come back. And we certainly will come back!

photos.caption: Photo of Yojié Japanese Fondue - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Angus beef prior to cooking in spicy miso broth
Photo of Yojié Japanese Fondue - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy miso both for cooking the meal

sY1BmEtGWgIsSds_6Hx1aQ.text: If you're ever in the mood to take your time and cook your own food at a restaurant, this place is definitely a great option. I don't have Japanese fondue often, but when I want some shabu shabu I always come here. I love the interior of this place, very modern, simple and clean. While you're enjoying your meal sitting at either the high top bar or the standard tables across, the TVs overhead are usually showing either Japanese game shows or anime, which has always made my dinner experience better. Their service is great. The staff always makes sure any new-timers know the how-to's of shabu shabu. The price is a bit high for a meal but the experience is worth it. Would definitely come back anytime.

EtR1eRUtuCItMA_fkGNylg.text: This was my first time ever trying Japanese fondu and this place is bomb!! I would recommend this place ten times over. I had such a good experience! When I told them it was my first time they made sure to show me how everything worked she helped me pick out which broth I wanted and gave me recommendations! Great customer service all over. I had the combo beef and chicken and it was amazing! It came with veggies and noodles and two pieces of tofu. You get to choose two sauces to go with your meat and veggies. Definitely try this place you won't be disappointed.

photos.caption: Photo of Yojié Japanese Fondue - Las Vegas, NV, United States. My little set up! Beef and chicken combo comes with rice veggies noodles tofu and you get to choose your broth!

TXV5mjVapuJfEfamvVt3yA.text: From the atmosphere to the food, this place was amazing!  The atmosphere of this place was so nice and quaint. The modern est style of the store is to die for. Also the fact that they had "Takeshi Castle" on while I was eating was a HUGE plus! I love that show so much.  Food is such a different style I have never had. The fondue style of eating was new to me and a pleasant surprise. Not only that but the Chocolate fondue at the end was to die for!! I was thinking of coming to this place again for the chocolate fondue ALONE!  If you have some time and want to try out an amazing, casual upscale elegant restaurant, With staff so nice and helpful, YOU SHOULD. DO IT because this place is worth a try, it will get your hooks into you.
